Title:
Westerdykella indica sp. nov., secreting plant
polysaccharide-degrading enzymes.
Keywords:
Phoma, Westerdykella dispersa, phylogenetic analysis,
taxonomy, glycosyl hydrolases
Abstract:
A xylanase producing thermotolerant fungal strain
(designated as AUMS62), isolated from soil sample containing plant
wreckage material, showed slow growth with white aerial and light brown
submerged mycelium. The novel species exhibited conidiogenesis on 7th
day of incubation on potato dextrose agar (26 °C) and cleistothecioid
ascomata on 14th day of incubation (40 °C). Colonies were floccose,
irregular having undulate margin with an umbonate elevation.
Phylogenetic analysis of the combined sequences of the internal
transcribed spacer, LSU rRNA and the β-tubulin genes confirmed the
species novelty within the genus Westerdykella. Growth pattern study of
the organism showed early hyphal growth, followed by pycnidia formation,
and changes in structural form of fruiting bodies upon 14 days of
incubation. Morphological and phylogenetic analysis suggest a novel
species Westerdykella indica and first report on extracellular glycosyl
hydrolases production. Xylanase and cellulase activities in the crude
fermentation extract were 1.855 and 0.234 IU ml-1 min-1,
respectively.
